abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with neurological symptoms, including autism spectrum disorder. Tuberous sclerosis complex is caused by pathogenic germline mutations of either the <jats:italic>TSC1</jats:italic> or <jats:italic>TSC2</jats:italic> gene, but somatic mutations were identified in both genes, and the combined effects of <jats:italic>TSC1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TSC2</jats:italic> mutations have been unknown.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The present study investigated social behaviors by the social interaction test and three-chambered sociability tests, effects of rapamycin treatment, and gene expression profiles with a gene expression microarray in <jats:italic>Tsc1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Tsc2</jats:italic> double heterozygous mutant (<jats:italic>TscD</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup>) mice.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p><jats:italic>TscD</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice exhibited impairments in social behaviors, and the severity of impairments was similar to <jats:italic>Tsc2</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice rather than <jats:italic>Tsc1</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice. Impairments in social behaviors were rescued by rapamycin treatment in all mutant mice. Gene expression profiles in the brain were greatly altered in <jats:italic>TscD</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice more than in <jats:italic>Tsc1</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>Tsc2</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice. The gene expression changes compared with wild type (WT) mice were similar between <jats:italic>TscD</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> and <jats:italic>Tsc2</jats:italic><jats:sup>+/−</jats:sup> mice, and the overlapping genes whose expression was altered in mutant mice compared with WT mice were enriched in the neoplasm- and inflammation-related canonical pathways. The “signal transducer and activator of transcription 3, interferon regulatory factor 1, interferon regulatory factor 4, interleukin-2R α chain, and interferon-γ” signaling pathway, which is initiated from signal transducer and activator of transcription 4 and PDZ and LIM domain protein 2, was associated with impairments in social behaviors in all mutant mice.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Limitations</jats:title>
                <jats:p>It is unclear whether the signaling pathway also plays a critical role in autism spectrum disorders not caused by <jats:italic>Tsc1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Tsc2</jats:italic> mutations.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>These findings suggest that <jats:italic>TSC1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TSC2</jats:italic> double mutations cause autistic behaviors similarly to <jats:italic>TSC2</jats:italic> mutations, although significant changes in gene expression were attributable to the double mutations. These findings contribute to the knowledge of genotype–phenotype correlations in TSC and suggest that mutations in both the <jats:italic>TSC1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TSC2</jats:italic> genes act in concert to cause neurological symptoms, including autism spectrum disorder.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

title: Tsc2 mutation rather than Tsc1 mutation dominantly causes a social deficit in a mouse model of tuberous sclerosis complex
